title: Organizing the Business

slides.title: Organizational Structure: The Framework for Success
content: Organizational structure defines how jobs are assigned and how they relate to each other, ensuring clarity and efficiency.
Organization charts offer a visual representation of the structure, showing job positions and chain of command for easy understanding.
Effective organizational design is essential for achieving goals and adapting to dynamic business environments, therefore leading to business success.
Business owners must make critical decisions to promote organizational effectiveness.
slides.script: Welcome to this lesson on 'Organizing the Business.' This chapter explores how businesses structure themselves to achieve their goals. First, we'll define organizational structure and explain its importance. We will also examine visual aids such as organization charts and highlight their benefits for employees.

slides.title: Factors Determining Organizational Structure
content: A company's mission shapes its structure. Fast growing, or more stable ventures require a different organizational setup.
Company size is a key determinant. As a business expands, the structure has to evolve to meet the new requirements of its growth.
The external environment plays a major role. Competitive landscapes may demand flexibility or structure to adapt quickly.
Organizational culture also influences the way a company functions.
slides.script: Now that we have discussed the meaning of the organizational structure, let's examine the factors that influence it. Mission and strategy, size, environment, and organizational culture all play vital roles in shaping the structure of a company. As the business grows, the structure should also adapt to the new requirements.

slides.title: Job Specialization: Dividing the Labor
content: Job specialization involves dividing complex tasks into manageable, specialized jobs to maximize overall efficiency.
Well-defined roles enable employees to develop expertise in specific areas, enhancing productivity and quality of work.
Over-specialization may lead to boredom and dissatisfaction, creating the potential for high employee turnover.
It is important to find a balance between effectiveness and flexibility in defining the range of employee duties.
slides.script: Job specialization is one of the foundational building blocks of organizational structure. It is the basis for creating a system where workers can maximize productivity. Let's discuss the balance you should consider, as well as the risks involved, when defining specialization.

slides.title: Departmentalization: Structuring the Organization
content: Departmentalization involves grouping specialized jobs into logical units, streamlining control and coordination.
Functional departmentalization organizes departments based on the activity performed, providing a clear structure.
Product departmentalization divides the organization by product, improving focus and accountability for specific goods or services.
Other options for departmentalization are: by process, by customer or by geography, allowing to best meet organizational needs.
slides.script: After defining specialized roles, we need to group them in ways that are efficient for completing organizational activities. Departmentalization is grouping jobs into logical units and can be based on functions, products, customers, or geographic regions. There are advantages to each approach, so it is important to choose the one that best suits the organization.

slides.title: Decision-Making Hierarchy: Authority and Power
content: The decision-making hierarchy establishes the levels of authority, dictating who makes decisions and how.
Centralization concentrates power at the top, ensuring consistency but potentially slowing responses.
Decentralization distributes power throughout the organization, promoting faster and localized decision making.
Distributing authority requires a clear delegation process: assign responsibility, grant authority, and create accountability.
slides.script: The decision-making hierarchy, in its different forms, is a powerful tool in the business world. It is a balance between centralization and decentralization that defines how authority is shared and delegated throughout the organization. Each structure has its own advantages and disadvantages, so we'll go over what you need to consider.

slides.title: Authority: Line vs. Staff
content: Line authority flows up and down the chain of command, directly impacting production and sales efforts.
Staff authority relies on expertise and offers advice to line managers in areas like law, accounting, or human resources.
Staff members have the authority to advise line managers, while line managers ultimately make the final decisions.
While both authority types are valuable, the distinction is often blurred, allowing for more adaptability.
slides.script: When discussing authority, it is important to differentiate between line and staff authority. Line authority directly impacts production and sales, while staff authority advises line managers. In both situations, accountability and authority are essential for smooth business operations.

slides.title: Forms of Authority: Teams and Committees
content: Committees consist of top managers from various areas, playing a central role in daily operations.
Teams are composed of employees empowered to plan, organize, and perform work with minimal oversight.
Teams improve communication, encourage collaboration, and facilitate faster decision making.
Committee authority grants decision-making power beyond individual authority, to benefit daily operations and increase influence.
slides.script: Besides authority resting with individuals, we also must recognize the role of teams and committees in the modern workplace. This structure allows for a more diverse range of perspectives, promoting better problem solving and buy-in from team members. When managed effectively, this process enables a team to be more effective.

slides.title: Functional Structure: Grouping by Expertise
content: The functional structure groups employees by expertise, such as marketing, operations, or finance.
Suitable for small to medium-sized firms, functional structures improve specialization and coordination.
As firms grow, functional structures become more complex and centralized, making accountability more difficult to track.
Despite their limitations, functional structures can be an invaluable basis for smaller organizations.
slides.script: Let's shift our focus now to the traditional forms of organizational structure. A functional structure relies on grouping employees according to their specialized areas of expertise. The key here is that the relationship between the groups helps dictate authority. Though this process can be invaluable in a small business, as a business grows, there can be limitations.

slides.title: Divisional Structure: Autonomous Units
content: Divisional structure relies on product departmentalization, dividing the organization into separate product-based divisions.
Each division operates as a relatively autonomous business under the larger umbrella, allowing the firm to become more adaptable.
These separate units may compete and increase business profits, and the structure is often more agile.
If too much control is delegated, however, corporate managers might lose touch with daily operations and division may become disruptive.
slides.script: Let's consider the divisional structure, in which business operations are structured around product-based divisions, allowing each division to function almost independently and to become more adaptable in a complex market. As a result, they may also compete and promote business effectiveness. With more control for the individual division, accountability becomes a key issue in the business plan.

slides.title: Matrix Structure: Flexible Collaboration
content: Matrix structure superimposes one organizational structure onto another, creating a combination that is often more effective.
This type of structure gets its name from having an appearance of a matrix in diagrams, creating both flexibility and adaptability.
Often, the matrix organization is implemented to complete a special project, then is broken up when its goals are completed.
Team members may come from finance, marketing, engineering, and other areas.
slides.script: While we are discussing the structures of organizations, let's discuss the matrix structure, which combines elements of functional and divisional structures to facilitate collaboration, innovation, and a more effective organizational structure. It provides organizations with greater flexibility to adapt as needed. The goal is to have a good project-management dynamic to reach specific goals.

slides.title: International Structure: Reaching Global Markets
content: The international structure is used by firms that actively manufacture, purchase, and sell in global markets.
International division of geographic areas allows for operations to better serve global markets.
Some organizations adopt a truly global structure in which resources are used without the consideration of boundaries.
International operations are separated into divisions and geographic areas, such as Mexico, Europe, Asia, and Africa.
slides.script: In a business world that is more and more interconnected, the international structure is essential for those that operate in global markets. Its organizational setup is focused on international markets and resources.

slides.title: Contemporary Forms of Organization: Building Innovation
content: Team organization relies almost exclusively on project-based teams, reducing the dependence on any functional hierarchy.
Virtual organizations, having little formal structure, use temporary workers and outsourced services to meet demand.
Learning organizations promote continuous improvement through lifelong learning and personal development for all employees.
These new forms of organization allow firms to stay flexible in a rapidly evolving business landscape.
slides.script: Organizational structures are continuously evolving to adapt to the fast-paced and complex world. Among the new options are team organizations, virtual organizations, and learning organizations. The goal of these structures is to enable to companies to reach a variety of goals and adapt effectively.

slides.title: Informal Organization: The Human Factor
content: Informal organization refers to everyday social interactions among employees that transcend formal roles and hierarchies.
Informal groups are defined as people who choose to interact among themselves, and their impact may be positive or negative.
The organizational grapevine is an informal communication network that can permeate the entire organization.
These influences may be leveraged in positive ways or may be seen as a potentially problematic human element.
slides.script: The informal organization is the social aspect of the business and includes both positive and negative impacts. It comprises everyday interactions among employees and has an impact on communications. Smart managers can harness its power to improve organizational effectiveness, while more naive managers may allow these forces to undermine the work of the company.

slides.title: Intrapreneuring: Cultivating Innovation Within
content: Intrapreneuring creates and maintains the innovation of a small-business environment within a large, bureaucratic structure.
Inventors create the new idea or service, but a product champion, usually a middle manager, helps to promote it.
The sponsor, usually a top-level manager, approves of and supports the project, often overcoming internal arguments.
Intrapreneuring encourages creativity and helps foster innovation for future business models.
slides.script: Let's conclude by discussing intrapreneuring. A key part of remaining competitive in the long run is innovation. Here, we have inventers who come up with and develop the new idea, product champions who promote it, and sponsors who push it from the top. Taken together, this approach creates a strong force for the entire business.

script: In conclusion, organizing a business requires a careful consideration of various factors, from the mission and size of the organization to the needs of its employees. By strategically structuring the organization, managers can create an environment where innovation and success are more easily achieved.
